meta.brief: Git blob load and write routines
meta.defgroup: git_blob Git blob load and write routines
git_commit Git commit parsing, formatting routines

meta.brief: Git error handling routines and variables
Git index parsing and manipulation routines
meta.defgroup: git_index Git index parsing and manipulation routines
git_repository Git revision object management routines
git_tree Git tree parsing, loading routines

args.name: blob
args.comment: pointer to the looked up blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the blob.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the blob to locate.

git_blob_lookup.description: Lookup a blob object from a repository. The generated blob object is owned by the revision repo and shall not be freed by the user.

args.name: repo
args.comment: The repository where the object will reside

git_blob_new.comments: The blob object must be manually filled using the 'set_rawcontent' methods before it can be written back to disk.

args.name: filename
args.comment: name of the file to read

git_blob_set_rawcontent_fromfile.description: Fill a blob with the contents inside the pointed file.

args.name: buffer
args.comment: buffer with the contents for the blob

git_blob_set_rawcontent.description: Fill a blob with the contents inside the pointed buffer

return.comment: the pointer; NULL if the blob has no contents

git_blob_rawcontent.description: Get a read-only buffer with the raw content of a blob.
git_blob_rawcontent.comments: A pointer to the raw content of a blob is returned; this pointer is owned internally by the object and shall not be free'd. The pointer may be invalidated at a later time (e.g. when changing the contents of the blob).

git_blob_rawsize.description: Get the size in bytes of the contents of a blob

args.name: written_id
args.comment: return the id of the written blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository where the blob will be written

args.name: path
args.comment: file from which the blob will be created

git_blob_writefile.description: Read a file from the working folder of a repository and write it to the Object Database as a loose blob, if such doesn't exist yet.

args.name: commit
args.comment: pointer to the looked up commit

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the commit.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the commit to locate. If the object is an annotated tag it will be peeled back to the commit.

git_commit_lookup.description: Lookup a commit object from a repository. The generated commit object is owned by the revision repo and shall not be freed by the user.

args.name: repo
args.comment: The repository where the object will reside

git_commit_new.comments: The commit object must be manually filled using setter methods before it can be written to its repository.

git_commit_id.description: Get the id of a commit. @param commit a previously loaded commit. @return object identity for the commit.

return.comment: the short message of a commit

git_commit_message_short.description: Get the short (one line) message of a commit. @param commit a previously loaded commit. @return the short message of a commit

git_commit_message.description: Get the full message of a commit. @param commit a previously loaded commit. @return the message of a commit

git_commit_time.description: Get the commit time (i.e. committer time) of a commit. @param commit a previously loaded commit. @return the time of a commit

git_commit_committer.description: Get the committer of a commit. @param commit a previously loaded commit. @return the committer of a commit

git_commit_author.description: Get the author of a commit. @param commit a previously loaded commit. @return the author of a commit

git_commit_tree.description: Get the tree pointed to by a commit. @param commit a previously loaded commit. @return the tree of a commit

args.name: new_parent
args.comment: the new commit which will be a parent

git_commit_add_parent.description: Add a new parent commit to an existing commit @param commit the commit object @param new_parent the new commit which will be a parent

git_commit_set_message.description: Set the message of a commit @param commit the commit object @param message the new message

args.name: time
args.comment: time when the committer committed the commit

git_commit_set_committer.argline: git_commit *commit, const char *name, const char *email, time_t time
git_commit_set_committer.description: Set the committer of a commit @param commit the commit object @param name name of the new committer @param email email of the new committer @param time time when the committer committed the commit

args.name: time
args.comment: time when the author created the commit

git_commit_set_author.argline: git_commit *commit, const char *name, const char *email, time_t time
git_commit_set_author.description: Set the author of a commit @param commit the commit object @param name name of the new author @param email email of the new author @param time time when the author created the commit

git_commit_set_tree.description: Set the tree which is pointed to by a commit @param commit the commit object @param tree the new tree

return.comment: a string explaining the error code

git_strerror.description: strerror() for the Git library @param num The error code to explain @return a string explaining the error code

args.name: index
args.comment: the pointer for the new index

args.name: index_path
args.comment: the path to the index file in disk

git_index_open_bare.description: Create a new Git index object as a memory representation of the Git index file in 'index_path', without a repository to back it.
git_index_open_bare.comments: Since there is no ODB behind this index, any Index methods which rely on the ODB (e.g. index_add) will fail with the GIT_EBAREINDEX error code.

args.name: index
args.comment: _path the path to the index file in disk

args.name: repo
args.comment: the git repo which owns the index

git_index_open_inrepo.description: Open the Index inside the git repository pointed by 'repo'.

git_index_clear.description: Clear the contents (all the entries) of an index object. This clears the index object in memory; changes must be manually written to disk for them to take effect.

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_read.description: Update the contents of an existing index object in memory by reading from the hard disk.

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_write.description: Write an existing index object from memory back to disk using an atomic file lock.

git_index_find.description: Find the first index of any entires which point to given path in the Git index.

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_add.description: Add or update an index entry from a file in disk.

args.name: position
args.comment: position of the entry to remove

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code
0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_insert.description: Insert an entry into the index. A full copy (including the 'path' string) of the given 'source_entry' will be inserted on the index; if the index already contains an entry for the same path, the entry will be updated.

return.comment: a pointer to the entry; NULL if out of bounds

git_index_get.description: Get a pointer to one of the entries in the index
git_index_get.comments: This entry can be modified, and the changes will be written back to disk on the next write() call.

return.comment: integer of count of current entries

git_index_entrycount.description: Get the count of entries currently in the index

args.name: out
args.comment: location to store the database pointer, if opened. Set to NULL if the open failed.

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if the database opened; otherwise an error code describing why the open was not possible.

git_odb_open.description: Open an object database for read/write access. @param out location to store the database pointer, if opened. Set to NULL if the open failed. @param objects_dir path of the database's "objects" directory. @return GIT_SUCCESS if the database opened; otherwise an error code describing why the open was not possible.

args.name: db
args.comment: database pointer to close. If NULL no action is taken.

git_odb_close.description: Close an open object database. @param db database pointer to close. If NULL no action is taken.

args.name: out
args.comment: object descriptor to populate upon reading.

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

return.comment: - GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read; - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

git_odb_read.comments: If GIT_ENOTFOUND then out->data is set to NULL.

args.name: out
args.comment: object descriptor to populate upon reading.

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

return.comment: - GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read; - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

git_odb_read_header.description: Read the header of an object from the database, without reading its full contents.
git_odb_read_header.comments:
Only the 'type' and 'len' fields of the git_rawobj structure are filled. The 'data' pointer will always be NULL.

The raw object pointed by 'out' doesn't need to be manually closed with git_obj_close().

args.name: out
args.comment: object descriptor to populate upon reading.

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

return.comment: - GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read. - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

git_odb__read_packed.description: Read an object from the database using only pack files.
git_odb__read_packed.comments: If GIT_ENOTFOUND then out->data is set to NULL.

args.name: out
args.comment: object descriptor to populate upon reading.

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

return.comment: - GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read. - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

git_odb__read_loose.description: Read an object from the database using only loose object files.
git_odb__read_loose.comments: If GIT_ENOTFOUND then out->data is set to NULL.

args.name: db
args.comment: database to which the object should be written.

args.name: obj
args.comment: object descriptor for the object to write.

return.comment: - GIT_SUCCESS if the object was written; - GIT_ERROR otherwise.

git_obj_close.description: Release all memory used by the obj structure.
git_obj_close.comments:
As a result of this call, obj->data will be set to NULL.

If obj->data is already NULL, nothing happens.

git_obj_type_to_string.description: Convert an object type to it's string representation.
git_obj_type_to_string.comments: The result is a pointer to a string in static memory and should not be free()'ed.

git_obj_string_to_type.description: Convert a string object type representation to it's git_otype.

return.comment: true if the type represents a valid loose object type, false otherwise.

git_obj__loose_object_type.description: Determine if the given git_otype is a valid loose object type.

args.name: obj
args.comment: the object whose hash is to be determined.

return.comment: - GIT_SUCCESS if the object-ID was correctly determined. - GIT_ERROR if the given object is malformed.

git_obj_hash.description: Determine the object-ID (sha1 hash) of the given git_rawobj.
git_obj_hash.comments: The input obj must be a valid loose object type and the data pointer must not be NULL, unless the len field is also zero.

args.name: db
args.comment: database to be searched for the given object.

return.comment: - true, if the object was found - false, otherwise

git_odb_exists.description: Determine if the given object can be found in the object database.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: str
args.comment: input hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes).

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if valid; GIT_ENOTOID on failure.

git_oid_mkstr.description: Parse a hex formatted object id into a git_oid. @param out oid structure the result is written into. @param str input hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes). @return GIT_SUCCESS if valid; GIT_ENOTOID on failure.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: raw
args.comment: the raw input bytes to be copied.

git_oid_mkraw.description: Copy an already raw oid into a git_oid structure. @param out oid structure the result is written into. @param raw the raw input bytes to be copied.

args.name: str
args.comment: output hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes). Only the oid digits are written; a '\\0' terminator must be added by the caller if it is required.

git_oid_fmt.description: Format a git_oid into a hex string. @param str output hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes). Only the oid digits are written; a '\0' terminator must be added by the caller if it is required. @param oid oid structure to format.

args.name: str
args.comment: output hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (41 bytes). Only the oid digits are written; a '\\0' terminator must be added by the caller if it is required.

git_oid_pathfmt.description:
Format a git_oid into a loose-object path string.

The resulting string is "aa/...", where "aa" is the first two hex digitis of the oid and "..." is the remaining 38 digits.

return.comment: the c-string; NULL if memory is exhausted. Caller must deallocate the string with free().

git_oid_allocfmt.description: Format a gid_oid into a newly allocated c-string. @param oid the oid structure to format @return the c-string; NULL if memory is exhausted. Caller must deallocate the string with free().

args.name: out
args.comment: the buffer into which the oid string is output.

args.name: n
args.comment: the size of the out buffer.

return.comment: the out buffer pointer, assuming no input parameter errors, otherwise a pointer to an empty string.

git_oid_to_string.description:
Format a git_oid into a buffer as a hex format c-string.

If the buffer is smaller than GIT_OID_HEXSZ+1, then the resulting oid c-string will be truncated to n-1 characters. If there are any input parameter errors (out == NULL, n == 0, oid == NULL), then a pointer to an empty string is returned, so that the return value can always be printed.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

git_oid_cpy.description: Copy an oid from one structure to another. @param out oid structure the result is written into. @param src oid structure to copy from.

git_oid_cmp.description: Compare two oid structures. @param a first oid structure. @param b second oid structure. @return <0, 0, >0 if a < b, a == b, a > b.

args.name: repository
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be opened

return.comment: the new repository handle; NULL on error

git_repository_open.comments:
The 'path' argument must point to an existing git repository folder, e.g.

/path/to/my_repo/.git/  (normal repository)
                    objects/
                    index
                    HEAD

/path/to/bare_repo/     (bare repository)
                objects/
                index
                HEAD

The method will automatically detect if 'path' is a normal or bare repository or fail is 'path' is neither.

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository to look up the object

args.name: id
args.comment: the unique identifier for the object

git_repository_lookup.argline: git_object **object, git_repository *repo, const git_oid *id, git_otype type
git_repository_lookup.description: Lookup a reference to one of the objects in the repostory.
git_repository_lookup.comments:
The generated reference is owned by the repository and should not be freed by the user.

The 'type' parameter must match the type of the object in the odb; the method will fail otherwise. The special value 'GIT_OBJ_ANY' may be passed to let the method guess the object's type.

return.comment: a pointer to the object db

git_repository_database.description: Get the object database behind a Git repository

return.comment: a pointer to the Index object; NULL if the index cannot be opened

git_repository_index.description: Get the Index file of a Git repository

args.name: object
args.comment: pointer to the new object @parem repo Repository where the object belongs

args.name: type
args.comment: Type of the object to be created

git_repository_newobject.description: Create a new in-memory repository object with the given type.
git_repository_newobject.comments:
The object's attributes can be filled in using the corresponding setter methods.

The object will be written back to given git_repository when the git_object_write() function is called; objects cannot be written to disk until all their main attributes have been properly filled.

Objects are instantiated with no SHA1 id; their id will be automatically generated when writing to the repository.

return.comment: 0 on success; otherwise an error code

git_object_write.comments:
The object will be written to its corresponding repository.

If the object has no changes since it was first read from the repository, no actions will take place.

If the object has been modified since it was read from the repository, or it has been created from scratch in memory, it will be written to the repository and its SHA1 ID will be updated accordingly.

git_object_id.description: Get the id (SHA1) of a repository object
git_object_id.comments: In-memory objects created by git_object_new() do not have a SHA1 ID until they are written on a repository.

git_object_type.description: Get the object type of an object

return.comment: the repository who owns this object

git_object_owner.description: Get the repository that owns this object

git_object_free.description: Free a reference to one of the objects in the repository.
git_object_free.comments:
Repository objects are managed automatically by the library, but this method can be used to force freeing one of the objects.

Careful: freeing objects in the middle of a repository traversal will most likely cause errors.

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository handle to close. If NULL nothing occurs.

git_repository_free.description: Free a previously allocated repository @param repo repository handle to close. If NULL nothing occurs.

args.name: walker
args.comment: pointer to the new revision walker

git_revwalk_new.description: Allocate a new revision walker to iterate through a repo.

git_revwalk_reset.description: Reset the walking machinery for reuse. @param walker handle to reset.

args.name: walk
args.comment: er the walker being used for the traversal.

git_revwalk_push.description: Mark a commit to start traversal from. The commit object must belong to the repo which is being walked through.

args.name: walk
args.comment: er the walker being used for the traversal.

args.name: commit
args.comment: the commit that will be ignored during the traversal

git_revwalk_hide.description: Mark a commit (and its ancestors) uninteresting for the output. @param walker the walker being used for the traversal. @param commit the commit that will be ignored during the traversal

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker to pop the commit from.

return.comment: next commit; NULL if there is no more output.

git_revwalk_next.description: Get the next commit from the revision traversal. @param walk the walker to pop the commit from. @return next commit; NULL if there is no more output.

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker being used for the traversal.

git_revwalk_sorting.description: Change the sorting mode when iterating through the repository's contents. Changing the sorting mode resets the walker. @param walk the walker being used for the traversal. @param sort_mode combination of GIT_RPSORT_XXX flags

args.name: walk
args.comment: traversal handle to close. If NULL nothing occurs.

git_revwalk_free.description: Free a revwalk previously allocated. @param walk traversal handle to close. If NULL nothing occurs.

git_revwalk_repository.description: Return the repository on which this walker is operating.

args.name: tag
args.comment: pointer to the looked up tag

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the tag.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the tag to locate.

git_tag_lookup.description: Lookup a tag object from the repository. The generated tag object is owned by the revision repo and shall not be freed by the user.

args.name: repo
args.comment: The repository where the object will reside

git_tag_new.comments: The tag object must be manually filled using setter methods before it can be written to its repository.

git_tag_id.description: Get the id of a tag. @param tag a previously loaded tag. @return object identity for the tag.

git_tag_target.description: Get the tagged object of a tag @param tag a previously loaded tag. @return reference to a repository object

git_tag_type.description: Get the type of a tag's tagged object @param tag a previously loaded tag. @return type of the tagged object

git_tag_name.description: Get the name of a tag @param tag a previously loaded tag. @return name of the tag

git_tag_tagger.description: Get the tagger (author) of a tag @param tag a previously loaded tag. @return reference to the tag's author

git_tag_message.description: Get the message of a tag @param tag a previously loaded tag. @return message of the tag

git_tag_set_target.description: Set the target of a tag (i.e. the object that the tag points to) @param tag The tag to modify @param target the new tagged target

args.name: name
args.comment: the new name for the tag

git_tag_set_name.description: Set the name of a tag @param tag The tag to modify @param name the new name for the tag

args.name: name
args.comment: the name of the new tagger

args.name: email
args.comment: the email of the new tagger

args.name: time
args.comment: the time when the tag was created

git_tag_set_tagger.argline: git_tag *tag, const char *name, const char *email, time_t time
git_tag_set_tagger.description: Set the tagger of a tag @param tag The tag to modify @param name the name of the new tagger @param email the email of the new tagger @param time the time when the tag was created

args.name: message
args.comment: the new tagger for the tag

git_tag_set_message.description: Set the message of a tag @param tag The tag to modify @param message the new tagger for the tag

args.name: tree
args.comment: pointer to the looked up tree

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the tree.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the tree to locate.

git_tree_lookup.description: Lookup a tree object from the repository. The generated tree object is owned by the revision repo and shall not be freed by the user.

args.name: repo
args.comment: The repository where the object will reside

git_tree_new.comments: The tree object must be manually filled using setter methods before it can be written to its repository.

git_tree_id.description: Get the id of a tree. @param tree a previously loaded tree. @return object identity for the tree.

return.comment: the number of entries in the tree

git_tree_entrycount.description: Get the number of entries listed in a tree @param tree a previously loaded tree. @return the number of entries in the tree

args.name: filename
args.comment: the filename of the desired entry

return.comment: the tree entry; NULL if not found

git_tree_entry_byname.description: Lookup a tree entry by its filename @param tree a previously loaded tree. @param filename the filename of the desired entry @return the tree entry; NULL if not found

args.name: idx
args.comment: the position in the entry list

return.comment: the tree entry; NULL if not found

git_tree_entry_byindex.description: Lookup a tree entry by its position in the tree @param tree a previously loaded tree. @param idx the position in the entry list @return the tree entry; NULL if not found

git_tree_entry_attributes.description: Get the UNIX file attributes of a tree entry @param entry a tree entry @return attributes as an integer

git_tree_entry_name.description: Get the filename of a tree entry @param entry a tree entry @return the name of the file

git_tree_entry_id.description: Get the id of the object pointed by the entry @param entry a tree entry @return the oid of the object

return.comment: a reference to the pointed object in the repository

git_tree_entry_2object.description: Convert a tree entry to the git_object it points too.

args.name: tree
args.comment: Tree object to store the entry @iparam id OID for the tree entry

args.name: attributes
args.comment: UNIX file attributes for the entry

git_tree_add_entry.argline: git_tree *tree, const git_oid *id, const char *filename, int attributes
git_tree_add_entry.description: Add a new entry to a tree.
git_tree_add_entry.comments: This will mark the tree as modified; the new entry will be written back to disk on the next git_object_write()

args.name: tree
args.comment: Tree where to remove the entry

return.comment: 0 on successful removal; GIT_ENOTFOUND if the entry wasn't found

git_tree_remove_entry_byindex.comments:
Index must be >= 0 and < than git_tree_entrycount().

This will mark the tree as modified; the modified entry will be written back to disk on the next git_object_write()

args.name: tree
args.comment: Tree where to remove the entry

return.comment: 0 on successful removal; GIT_ENOTFOUND if the entry wasn't found

git_tree_remove_entry_byname.comments: This will mark the tree as modified; the modified entry will be written back to disk on the next git_object_write()

args.name: entry
args.comment: Entry object which will be modified

args.name: oid
args.comment: new SHA1 oid for the entry

git_tree_entry_set_id.description: Change the SHA1 id of a tree entry.
git_tree_entry_set_id.comments: This will mark the tree that contains the entry as modified; the modified entry will be written back to disk on the next git_object_write()

args.name: entry
args.comment: Entry object which will be modified

git_tree_entry_set_name.description: Change the filename of a tree entry.
git_tree_entry_set_name.comments: This will mark the tree that contains the entry as modified; the modified entry will be written back to disk on the next git_object_write()

args.name: entry
args.comment: Entry object which will be modified

git_tree_entry_set_attributes.description: Change the attributes of a tree entry.
git_tree_entry_set_attributes.comments: This will mark the tree that contains the entry as modified; the modified entry will be written back to disk on the next git_object_write()

return.comment: maximum length of the compressed data.

deflateBound.description: deflateBound returns an upper bound on the compressed size.
deflateBound.comments: This is a stub function used when zlib does not supply the deflateBound() implementation itself.

GIT_EXTERN(type).comments: Declare a public function exported for application use.

GIT_EXTERN_TLS(type).comments: Declare a public TLS symbol exported for application use.

GIT_FORMAT_PRINTF(a,b).comments: Declare a function's takes printf style arguments.

GIT_ERROR.comments: Operation failed, with unspecified reason. This value also serves as the base error code; all other error codes are subtracted from it such that all errors are < 0, in typical POSIX C tradition.

GIT_ENOTOID.comments: Input was not a properly formatted Git object id.

GIT_ENOTFOUND.comments: Input does not exist in the scope searched.

GIT_EOBJTYPE.comments: The specified object is of invalid type

GIT_EOBJCORRUPTED.comments: The specified object has its data corrupted

GIT_EINVALIDTYPE.comments: The object type is invalid or doesn't match

GIT_EMISSINGOBJDATA.comments: The object cannot be written that because it's missing internal data

GIT_EPACKCORRUPTED.comments: The packfile for the ODB is corrupted

GIT_EFLOCKFAIL.comments: Failed to adquire or release a file lock

GIT_EZLIB.comments: The Z library failed to inflate/deflate an object's data

GIT_EBAREINDEX.comments: The index file is not backed up by an existing repository

GIT_OID_HEXSZ.comments: Size (in bytes) of a hex formatted oid

GIT_SORT_NONE.comments: Sort the repository contents in no particular ordering; this sorting is arbitrary, implementation-specific and subject to change at any time. This is the default sorting for new walkers.

GIT_SORT_TOPOLOGICAL.comments: Sort the repository contents in topological order (parents before children); this sorting mode can be combined with time sorting.

GIT_SORT_TIME.comments: Sort the repository contents by commit time; this sorting mode can be combined with topological sorting.

GIT_SORT_REVERSE.comments: Iterate through the repository contents in reverse order; this sorting mode can be combined with any of the above.

types.block:
git_index_time ctime

char *path
types.comments: Memory representation of a file entry in the index.
Time used in a git index entry
Representation of a generic object in a repository
Unique identity of any object (commit, tree, blob, tag).

sections: Basic type (loose or packed) of any Git object.
